awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Assessing Long-Term Sociocultural Impacts in Disaster Recovery Efforts
awd_abstract_narration:
Recovery efforts following natural disasters are notoriously fraught with challenges. While recovery efforts are initially aided by large amounts of government and private contributions, appropriate assessment requires consideration of a range of variables that might influence the pace of recovery. This project explores what happens once the media attention has ebbed and aid organizations begin to leave the area. Do these disasters and the recovery efforts result in long-term sociocultural changes, and what are the implications for those changes on development and economic revitalization of these areas? As a Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award, the project integrates research and training to more effectively reinforce the infrastructure necessary to conduct effective scientific research. Funds would support graduate students with scientific and methodological training, field experience, and support in completing their theses. Widely-disseminated results will help inform future humanitarian policy and practice, and would forge international scientific cooperation in area of disaster recovery. 

Mark Schiller of Northern Illinois University explores the question of what long term changes to local socio-cultural institutions remain following the end of an aid or development project. Haiti's 2010 earthquake was one of the world's deadliest disasters in recent memory. It also inspired one of the most generous international humanitarian responses ever attempted. Despite the continuing global recession, governments pledged over $10 billion and private citizens contributed over $3 billion. The proposed research will offer methodological insights into ethnographic evaluation of INGOs (international non-governmental organizations) in disaster recovery efforts. The proposed five-year research project uses a purposive sample of eight rural communities with differing presence of humanitarian and development INGOs before and after the earthquake. While the researcher conducts interviews with donor, state, and organizational representatives, a team of graduate students shares responsibilities for participant observation and interview methods on social indicators, including level of dependence, independent mobilization, spatial organization, and what the researcher has termed "civic infrastructure," noting evolution over time. The educational component includes a research methods seminar in Haiti and a two-week Field School training, held concurrently with an NGO Summer Institute at Northern Illinois University.

por.por_cntn:
Whether long-term changes triggered by humanitarian aid following the 2010 earthquake (Schuller 2016a) were confined to Port-au-Prince, and whether they remain after NGOs leave, are urgent questions for the future of Haiti’s development, and understanding NGOs overall. The research compared eight provincial fieldsites in the “Grand South” of Haiti, teasing out variables of humanitarian versus development assistance and the impact on fieldsites with many NGOs before 2010’s earthquake compared to those with minimal NGO presence.

 

The dataset is voluminous: 1900 mixed-method surveys of 92 questions within eight fieldsites spanning three years, before and after a major disaster (2016, Hurricane Matthew), as well as over 150 interview transcripts. During the pandemic research activity was suspended, but colleagues and research assistants engaged local community leaders in meetings to validate and explain the data, identifying theoretical conclusions and practical solutions.

 

During the research tenure, 17 graduate students in the U.S. worked on the project. Of these students, 15 were women and 14 were BIPOC individuals, including 13 Black students. Six of these students are now assistant professors, and an additional two students completed their PhD (three completed their Master’s degree based on this work). RAs noted mentoring and preparation as important to their success. The State University of Haiti completed a research laboratory with grant funds, and four Haitian students completed MAs using data from the research, and one began her PhD at a university in Canada. In addition, training materials were translated into Haitian Creole, and reports on Hurricane Matthew were posted. The PI also keynoted two international conferences and published numerous blogs; in 2021 he was interviewed by a dozen media outlets.

 

Findings from the study of seven communities across the southern peninsula of Haiti, verified by focus group meetings in each community, demonstrate that local populations have ambivalent understandings of NGOs. Few could define them, and many conflate them with donors, government agencies, and even for-profit companies. In addition, INGO aid received did not match locally defined priorities, increased division in communities, and demobilized the community while offering temporary relief. Articles published from the project by Haitian MA students argue that NGOs reinforce racist ontologies: NGOs represent blan, foreigners, closer to God (Voltaire 2020), and that NGO aid is a tool in political contests (Lamartinère 2020; Saint Louis 2020).

 

Research also showed that overall, people’s evaluations of all entities involved – NGOs, the state, and local authorities – diminished following Hurricane Matthew. Interestingly women were less likely to be critical than men, particularly regarding the state. While often posited as a “zero sum” relationship between NGOs and states, people who reported receiving aid had significantly higher evaluation of and trust in all actors. Findings suggest that to the public, the state still has responsibility for overall wellbeing, and people hold local authorities responsible for presence or absence of NGOs. Data also suggest that the interrelationship between sets of actors – an aspect of what the PI termed “civic infrastructure” (2012) – shapes the outcomes: productive relationships can lead to progress and resilience. Trust in local organizations varied considerably, but there is a correlation between local groups’ organizing and local perception of effective outcomes. Also, social network data reveal a high degree of cooperation and sharing. However, some practices such as sòl, zero-interest lending circles, diminished after the influx and depart of INGO aid.

 

The final project activities include a Guide to the Humanitarian System, Development Aid, and NGOs for each of the communities. The Guides, published online and in paper format, in English and Haitian Creole, were accompanied by five local conferences with over 200 people attending, and community radio spots, brochures, and local workshops. The goal of the Guide is to bring all the stakeholders of humanitarian and development aid closer together, so that survivors and crisis affected communities are the ones leading responses to disaster or conflict.

 

Each Guide has three parts: the first aims at educating the general public about the humanitarian system; the second aims to empower recipient communities with knowledge about how this system is structured and functions, along with rights humanitarian conventions grant them; and the third aims to educate humanitarian agencies on how to approach the community, to identify assets the community has in addition to its priority needs, a “social map” identifying leaders and important public spaces, and a step-by-step guide to engaging the community and communication strategies.
